sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Surveying the horrors of war, the UN Secretary General tours Ukrainian towns ravaged by Russia's invasion and calls for accountability.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Is the EU united over Russian gas? A day after Gazprom cuts off Poland and Bulgaria, some of Europe's largest energy groups plan to open ruble accounts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Russia accuses the West of openly inciting Ukraine to attack Russia, warning there'd be a tough military response to any aggression on its territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And social media companies have been accused of failing to tackle online Islamophobia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We'll take a look at a new report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey, glad you could join us. The UN Secretary General says that war in the 21st century is an absurdity. Antonio Guterres made his remarks as he visited Ukraine on Thursday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Ahead of talks with President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv, the UN chief visited sites around the capital that had been occupied by Russian troops.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Since their withdrawal from the region, Russia's been focusing its assault to the east and south of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Witnessing the scale of destruction in the towns of Borydjanka, Bucha and Erpin, Guterres condemned the war but stopped short of blaming Moscow directly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Guterres condemned the war but stopped short of blaming Moscow directly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: What I feel, I imagine my family in one of those houses that is now destroyed and black. I see my granddaughters running away in panic, part of the family eventually killed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: running away in panic. Part of the family eventually killed. So the war is an absurdity in the 21st century. The war is evil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: One of Germany's largest energy firms has given in to Russia's newly imposed ruble demand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Unipers says it will pay in euros, which will be converted into rubles, a move that critics say will undermine EU sanctions placed on Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It's been reported that other European energy firms are preparing to do the same after Vladimir Putin demanded that countries he considers unfriendly must pay for gas in rubles or be cut off. Putin's already cut supplies to Poland and Bulgaria after they refused.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Bulgaria's prime minister is urging the rest of Europe to follow their lead.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: I think these unilateral moves that Putin is doing would only hurt him in the long run. I mean, who wants to trust a supplier that can change unilaterally the contract? Today will be that we have to pay in rubles, tomorrow will be the price, the next day will be the quantities. Well in the Bulgarian capital Sofia we can cross over now to Jack Parrick who's reporting from there. Jack good to see you. We heard there from the Bulgarian Prime Minister who was resolute that Bulgaria will not be capitulating to Russia's demand for payment in rubles but what are the Bulgarian government's plans to make up the shortfall?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, they've announced a plan that they will bring in at least 20 billion cubic metres of gas from Turkey and Greece combined.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That's the sort of initial plan at the moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: They're trying to dampen the concerns around this, saying simply that they do have enough to last in reserves for a while, that they have enough to go forward.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Bulgaria is somewhere in the region, Helena, of 90 to 95 percent reliant on imports of Russian gas. So this is going to be a concern, despite what they're saying. They think they've got a few weeks left in the tank. But But obviously, the people here are starting to question why the Bulgarian government is standing so resolute when they're seeing other countries, other companies, gas companies in other countries in the European Union making this decision to start paying in rubles when their government is saying that they won't. That's very big question isn't it jack and of course bulgaria poland i mean these are not uh the only countries not to pay in the way that russia wants so do we know why they've been targeted specifically well it's a really complicated one the russian president vladimir, Vladimir Putin, said that they made these moves against unfriendly countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The Polish government is staunchly anti-Russian on, firstly, the invasion of Ukraine, but also on a lot of other issues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Here in Bulgaria, it's slightly more complicated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: There are quite big pro-Russian political factions, and a number of experts have been suggesting that Bulgaria was targeted as it is a country that sort of banning the gas could mean that those political factions could sort of become more vocal against this coalition government here in Bulgaria, which is on very shaky ground at the moment over a number of issues, including the issue of sending arms into Ukraine. There is another discussion going on here in Bulgaria around the gas, though, and that is that Bulgaria has the power to actually cut off some of the transit routes, for instance, into Serbia, its northwestern neighbor, of Russian gas. And, obviously, Serbia is an extremely pro-Russia country at the moment as well. The government says that it wouldn't do that, that it wouldn't play the dirty tricks that it says the Kremlin is playing on Bulgaria, Helena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Well, Jack, that certainly is a very interesting dynamic to throw into the mix. Jack Parrick there reporting from Sofia in Bulgaria. Jack, good to talk to you. But we can go straight over now to Shona Murray, who is covering this story from Brussels. Good evening to you. We've heard that Bulgaria is standing firm. It's not giving in to Russian demands to pay in rubles. But is that unity holding across the board in the EU? Well, this is the key question. Of course, we know, for example, that there's tentative agreement on a new sixth sanctions package, which will be targeting oil. and we know that Bulgaria and Poland and the EU as itself has saying that they won't give in to Russian demands because of course that would be a breach of EU sanctions but we've also heard from Hungary saying suggesting that it possibly will pay in rubles and which also would be a breach of EU sanctions and also some companies but I caught up with Valdis Dombrovskis, who's the EU's executive vice president, also trade commissioner, and he made the point that the EU has been preparing for this decision by the Kremlin to cut off gas supplies. And why, while it's not without its difficulties, the EU can cope?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We've been doing this assessment already at the beginning of Russia's invasion in Ukraine. Paldies! And the assessment is that not without problems, but we are able to cope with this situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And we are already for some time very intensively working on diversifying gas supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The EU's executive vice president of the European Commission and EU's trade commissioner, Valdis Dombrovski, is there, making the point that the EU has been diversifying away from relying on Russian fossil fuels, in particular Russian oil and gas, and it will eventually be able to do this. The question is of course, Helena, when?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Let me ask you this though, Shona, if this is a potential breach of EU sanctions, could the EU crack down on this? Well the EU has been pretty clear today that the demands by the Kremlin for companies and countries to open a second bank account with Gazprom Bank, a ruble account, would be a breach of the EU sanctions and it's up to each member state to ensure that the sanctions are being implemented by companies as well as the governments.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So the EU has said that it can initiate legal infringement proceedings against member states if they're not implementing the sanctions or knowingly, of course, circumventing sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: President Biden has asked the U.S. Congress for an additional 31 billion euros in emergency funding to support Ukraine with weapons and economic assistance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The US Air Force has already started flying long range artillery pieces into Europe, as well as anti-tank weapons and armed switchback drones with a combined value of three and a half billion euros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Other Western partners are contributing a billion and a quarter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, Biden says the extra funding is essential if America is to keep backing Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's not cheap, but caving to aggression is going to be more costly if we allow it to happen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We either back Ukrainian people as they defend their country, or we stand by as the Russians continue their atrocities and aggression in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Every day, every day, the Ukrainians pay for the price with the price they pay with their lives for this fight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So we need to contribute arms, funding, ammunition, and the economic support to make their courage and sacrifice have purpose so they can continue this fight and do what they're doing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's critical this funding gets approved and approved as quickly as possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, Russia is warning the West to stop encouraging Ukraine to carry out strikes inside its territory. The Ukrainian army has completed several daring raids on military infrastructure inside of Russia using helicopters and drones. It's done so with advice and weaponry from Western countries and Russia says any further attempts will be met with a tough response.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: This kind of criminal action by the Ukrainian armed forces against Russia cannot go unanswered.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: We would like Kyiv and Western capitals to seriously take our defence ministry's statements that further attempts to incite Ukraine to strike Russian targets will definitely trigger a tough response and the Western advisors stationed in Ukrainian decision-making centres will not necessarily become a hindrance to Russia's response. Let's take this straight over then to our correspondent Galina Polonskaya to get the Russian perspective on this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Galina, we've heard from Moscow warning the West saying don't test our patience further, accusing them of inciting Ukraine to attack Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: We are two months now into this war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: So why this warning now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Hello, Helena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Hello, Helena. Well, indeed, in recent days, Russia has reported about a series of attacks in various regions – Voronezh, Kursk, Belgorod – accusing Ukraine of such, as it says, illegal actions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And we know that Ukraine has not taken this responsibility, just calling it karma so russia right now says that the west and the uk in particular are provoking ukraine to target russian territory and to target russia so the commerçant newspaper today quoted the british defense secretary who said that it would be legitimate for ukrainian forces to target russian logistics for example and we have heard the spokeswoman of the russian foreign ministry maria zakharova who spoke about the west provoking ukraine to target russia and she said quote do not i advise you not to test Russian patients any further and earlier the Russian defense ministry had also spoken about those um provocations director as it said provocations and warned about an immediate proportional response if such actions as it said were carried out and today there was one more warning, Helena, from the Kremlin, President Putin's spokesperson Dmitry Peskov has warned Europe. He said that the tendency to pump weapons to Ukraine are actions that threaten the security of the continent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, Galina, you mentioned there accusations being leveled at Europe, but we've also seen accusations going towards the US.S. and Poland, Russia's foreign spy chief, accusing them of plotting to gain a sphere of influence in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: What does that mean?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Exactly, Helena, and that's what the Russian state media are widely reporting today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Sergei Naryshkin, the chief of russia's foreign intelligence service as we are claimed quoting unspecified intelligence data that the us and poland are planning to install um polish control over parts of the western ukraine there was a statement published by the svr which says according to the intelligence received Washington and Warsaw are working on plans to establish Poland's tight military and political control over its historical possessions in Ukraine so it also says that the plan is to bring Polish peacekeepers without the NATO mandate inside some parts in the western Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And some top politicians in Russia are also claiming that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And as I said, the Russian state media are reporting this very, very widely.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: All right.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, a few Western allies spared by the Kremlin today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Bringing us the latest, Galina Polonskaya.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Galina, good to talk to you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Welcome back. Good to have you with us. today bringing us the latest Galina Polanskaya Galina good to talk to you welcome back good to have you with us well a new study says that all five major social media companies have ignored up to 90% of Islamophobic content

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: reported by users that since 2019 some neglecting up to 97% of reports to unravel these latest findings. We can go straight over to Matthew in the Cube now. Well Helena, this report is just the latest to say that social media companies are not doing enough to tackle online hate speech. Researchers at the Center for Countering Digital Hate say that up to 89% of the Islamophobic content that they found on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, Twitter and YouTube has not been removed, even when they flagged and reported it to the big tech companies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Facebook and Twitter have been found to be particularly poor. Twitter, according to researchers, has failed to remove 97% of anti-Muslim posts that were found. And researchers also said they came across some very offensive anti-Islamophobic hashtags on the likes of Instagram and TikTok, which had gained at least 1.3 million likes and shares.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now, in the past, social media companies have been accused of using their algorithms to exploit emotional content like hate speech and allow people to keep scrolling, which therefore earns the platforms more revenue. And the concern is that by failing to remove online Islamophobia this could potentially lead to offline real-world violence. And also worth noting that a lot of these social media companies had signed up to an international Christchurch call to remove extremist content after 51 people were killed by a white supremacist in terror attacks in New Zealand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This latest report says that those social media companies are not keeping the promises that they made back in 2019.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well here in the Cube we reached out to the big tech companies who all have rules against online hate that is directed towards a certain group or religion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: TikTok have since strengthened their enforcement policies and a Twitter spokesperson says they are also committed to preventing online hate and prejudice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Of course, the new owner, Elon Musk, says that he wants the platform to become a champion of free speech.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But his latest study, Helena, says that when it comes to Islamophobia, Musk, Twitter and indeed other social media companies still have a long way to go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: All right, Matthew and team in the cube there, keeping the big tech accountable. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, the World Health Organization is warning of a perfect storm as cases of measles soar around the world it says that the pandemic has interrupted global inoculation campaigns for non-covid diseases which could trigger large outbreaks of diseases which normally are preventable with vaccines for more on this now we can cross to rebecca daunt reported cases of measles soared by nearly 80 worldwide in the first two months of this year that's according to the world health organization and unicef in ukraine with the ongoing war leading to severe disruptions in the health system, including routine immunizations, the WHO is seriously concerned about a potential measles outbreak. Child vaccination campaigns were knocked off course around the world during the coronavirus pandemic. Immunization campaigns for diseases like typhoid and polio were also disrupted.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: This week is World Immunisation Week, an opportunity to highlight the incredible power of vaccines, not just to save lives, but in the words of Desir Thim, to offer the opportunity of a long life for all. But around the world, the pandemic has caused severe disruptions to routine immunization programs, putting millions of children's lives at risk and opening the door to fresh outbreaks of measles and polio." The UN agency and UNICEF said it was imperative to get the vaccine drive back on track. The five countries with the largest measles outbreaks in the last 12 months were Somalia, Liberia, Yemen, Afghanistan and the Ivory Coast. There have been 21 major outbreaks during this period. A new investigation claims that the EU's border agency Frontex has forced back over 950 asylum seekers in the Aegean Sea between March 2020 and September 2021. Five European media outlets have claimed that many illegal pushbacks were falsely logged with the incident being described as people being stopped from departing the territorial waters of a non-EU country. Frontex which is currently under EU investigation due to separate issues, has denied the allegations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Liverpool were 2-0 victors over Villarreal in their Champions League semi-final first leg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: To discuss the game and talk through the other football stories, sports reporter Michael Kern joins us now from London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Michael, perhaps not the most thrilling game or maybe not as thrilling as Tuesday's game, but nevertheless, Liverpool hold a two-goal lead heading into the second leg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Will it be enough to see them through to the final, do you think?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, you're completely right. It wasn't quite a seven-goal thriller, was it, like the night before, but they did what they had to do, a two-goal victory at Anfield for them, which kind of gives them a good footing going into that next leg, of course, next week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A 2-0 victory for them. They had to be patient with it. Of course, goals coming in the second half.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But many people saying Villarreal didn't really show up like they should have done on the night as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So who knows? Of course, the next leg is away for Liverpool. Villarreal will need to step up and show us that class.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: They showed us, of course, against Bayern Munich and Juventus in those previous rounds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So it's certainly not a done deal yet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's two goals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But you would have to say the way Liverpool are playing at the moment, the way they dominated, of course, that game as well last night, that I think it's fair to say they've certainly got one foot into that final already.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, Michael, another bit of good news then for Liverpool fans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Confirmation at the last hour that Jurgen Klopp will be staying at Anfield through till 2026.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: How important is it for Liverpool that they've got a few more seasons with the German? Well I think it's massive you know look at how the side has developed over these last few years of course firstly for them winning that first title in years which of course was incredibly important for them winning the Premier League their success in Europe of course as well under Jurgen Klopp I think for them as well having him secured for the next two years is really important. There was rumours that he was planning on to quit in 2024, but I think there's still lots more to come from this Liverpool side.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: You sense they're on the verge of this very important quadruple that could potentially happen this year. And lots of people are saying in the media that this Liverpool team is incredibly special and one of the best teams they've seen in a long while. So I think the job certainly isn't done for Jurgen Klopp.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And one of the main reasons he gave for wanting to stay is because his wife wants to stay in Merseyside.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So Liverpool's obviously made a good impression, not just on him, but his family as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Who can blame her?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: There are also reports that football agent Mina Raiola, who represents some of football's biggest players, had died.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: However, this is a very curious story. It turns out that this was not the case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: No, not the case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: He is very ill, though, we have to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: He's been in hospital since January, and one of the head anaesthetists at the intensive care unit in Milan, where he is, says that he was outraged by the phone calls from journalists trying to speculate on the life of a man who's fighting for his life.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: His right-hand man has come out and said he is in a very bad position, but he hasn't died. And someone else saying he's very, very ill. So no, he hasn't died. Real Madrid tweeted their condolences, and that tweet was quickly taken down. But yeah, he's certainly not very well, but he is still with us, and he hasn't passed away, as some of those rumors on Twitter were speculating a little bit earlier. And he did put a tweet out as well saying he wasn't too happy about the rumours either. So yeah, we wish him well and wish him a good speedy recovery. Absolutely wishing him all of the best.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Michael Kern in London as ever, good to talk to you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: And you're up to date. I'll see you soon.
